title: Urban Biodiversity Case Study
text:
Today’s Learning Goals

Define and give an example of Nature’s Contributions to People
Describe how the impacts of the Emerald Ash Borer in Canadian cities are connected to urban biodiversity
Argue why urban biodiversity is important with two or more lines of reasoning

title: Urban Biodiversity Case Study
text:
Urban Biodiversity



What is biodiversity?

Species richness
Evenness
Functional

Increased biodiversity at one trophic level provides opportunity for increased biodiversity at the next

With some exceptions

title: Urban Biodiversity Case Study
text:
Nature’s Contributions to People1

All the contributions of living nature to people’s quality of life
Culturally dependent and often context-specific
Built on the framework of “ecosystem services

Díaz et al., 2018, Science, doi: 10.1126/science.aap8826

title: Urban Biodiversity Case Study
text:
Nature’s Contributions to People

Frontiers for Young Minds
ask for examples of material, non-material, and regulating contributions in their lives - can we extend to the idea of context specific contributions?

title: Urban Biodiversity Case Study
text:
Nature’s Contributions in Cities

80% of Quebecers (and Canadians) live in cities
The majority of our interactions with nature happen in cities
We experience positive and negative contributions

One example is temperature regulation by trees
https://shorturl.at/ueCcT

title: Urban Biodiversity Case Study
text:
Biodiversity as a Contribution

Is biodiversity contributing to urban residents’ quality of life? How so?



if we are trying to increase or maximize one single contribution, often more biodiversity doesn’t necessarily help with this.
there are often specific species that contribute most to a specific set of contributions
